awd_titl_txt: A Pathway to Completion for Pursuing Engineering and Engineering Technology Degrees
awd_abstract_narration:
With funding from the NSF Scholarships in Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (S-STEM) program, the ?Pathway to Completion for Pursuing Engineering and Engineering Technology Degrees? project will support high-achieving, low-income students with demonstrated financial need.  The project will support students in STEM disciplines at the Frank Batten College of Engineering and Technology (BCET) at Old Dominion University (ODU) in Virginia.  This project will fund 70 scholarships over five years for BCET students who are pursuing bachelor's degrees in engineering and engineering technology. The project will include recruitment of veterans who have exhausted their GI Bill Benefits, but have not yet completed their STEM degree.  In addition to scholarships, the program will provide students with academic and mentoring support to increase academic success and workplace readiness, ensuring these students are ready to meet the demands of regional businesses near ODU.

This S-STEM Track 2 project builds on several existing initiatives at Old Dominion University, and introduces additional effective student support practices targeted at areas expected to be particularly critical to student success.  Through interventions and targeted support, the project aims to address the significant barriers and risk factors to degree completion of students pursuing engineering and engineering technology programs. The associated research activities will increase understanding of successful ways to support and encourage student success in STEM. This project has the potential to provide a model for how to retain student interest and participation throughout the completion of their degree.  Qualitative and quantitative data will be collected to gather information about self-efficacy and the value and cost of education of participating students, especially veterans. The lessons learned in this study will be relevant to other institutions of higher learning, and military services may be able to use these findings to better prepare service members as they transition from military service to higher education.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The central goal this project was to provide scholarships and student support services to veteran and adult students who experience significant barriers to degree completion in the Frank Batten College of Engineering and Technology (BCET), Old Dominion University. The intervention provided scholarships to eligible student veterans who have exhausted their G.I. benefits, and/or to adult students who demonstrate financial need as defined by Financial Aid Office, and, who demonstrated academic promise, a 3.00 or higher GPA. Marketing efforts to identify project participants targeted students in: Civil and Environmental Engineering, Electrical and Computer Engineering, Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering, Modeling and Simulation Engineering, and Engineering Technology. These students fulfill a critical STEM workforce need in the Hampton Roads Area and the greater Department of Defense community. Students participated in academic support services and activities designed to alleviate many of the risk factors faced by adult non-completers. Academic support provided by this project included academic tutoring and mentoring, as well a weekly required non-credit course that emerged as a supportive adult student learning community. Career development included exposure to practicing engineers in the field, the development of a professional website that posted internship and career opportunities, and assistance with applications for these professional positions. This project could be considered as a pilot-project that exemplifies best-practices for achieving veteran and adult student academic success and retention.

Qualitative Results: Content Analysis of Comments on Camaraderie, Career Awareness, Engineering Identity, Professional Development, Engineering Self Efficacy, Financial Security. Results suggest students valued the seminar (intervention) and developed a collegial learning community. Comon comments repeated across all semesters/years regarding the impact and the value of the seminar include :Camaraderie. Participants appreciated having the opportunity to meet students much like themselves, e.g., older adult students with military backgrounds – veterans. As students became closer over time, they felt safe to voice their frustrations with balancing academics, family, and work obligations, as well as talking about sometimes having issues with self-motivation.Career Awareness. Participants frequently stated that information on the various scholarships and career opportunities and how to evaluate them was invaluable. Participants better understood requirements  for professional exams/certifications. They also frequently mentioned being unaware of the vastness of their profession causing them to ponder future steps.Engineering Identity. Hearing from speakers who were professionals in the field, and who were themselves veterans, provided an appreciation for how military experience prepared them for an engineering profession. The presentations gave them a better understanding of the day-to-day activities that engineers perform.Professional Development. Participants expressed gratitude for the academic support received to help with developing cover letters, resumes, and follow-up letters. They commented they appreciated learning about interviewing including how to dress appropriately and learning about table etiquette.Engineering Self Efficacy. Participants commented on feeling better on pursuing an engineering degree and their future success as a practicing engineer in the field.Financial Security. Participants shared the scholarship alleviated much of the financial burdens they were experiencing. Students expressed the scholarship enabled them to dedicate more time to academics affecting their perceptions of being able to successfully graduate.

Qualitative Results: Content Analysis of Suggestions on how to Improve Content and Process of Seminar (Intervention). Participants were asked to make suggestions regarding how to improve on the content and/or the process of subsequent semesters/years of the seminar.  Comments  commonly repeated across all semesters/years are highlighted below:Content. As to be expected, many participants wanted to hear more about their specific field of engineering, and in some cases, more about specific industries, e.g., construction, aerospace, renewable energy. Several wanted to hear more from women engineers as they were exposed to few in their courses. Even though much of the industry in the Hampton Roads area is government or government-contract related, several participants wanted to hear more about non-government related career opportunities. Given the challenges of COVID, many participants requested to hear more about how COVID was impacting the workplace.Process: One of the most interesting comments from several participants was on how they thought the content of the seminar was invaluable and should be available to all engineering students, notjust those in the Pathways project. Some students commented that they would like to see workshops developed around specific tools, e.g., MatLab, 3-D printing, programming, etc. Many students expressed that they thought the seminar, though required, should be for-credit and that they would not mind doing assignments for class, e.g., reading about and writing brief papers on companies from which presenters came before their visit to class, etc. Several students commented that they would like increased opportunities to interact, both in- and outside-of-class. Before COVID, several students expressed interest in opportunities to shadow practicing engineers in the field, and that they would like more field trips. Participants also commented that the use of ZOOM should be continued as it would permit non-local speakers to give presentations in the seminar.


Last Modified: 10/09/2023
Modified by: Anthony W Dean
